scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In this autograph letter, William H. Herndon questions the authenticity of Abraham Lincoln's reply to "a Committee of Colored People" of Baltimore who in 1864 visited the White House to present him with a Bible. According to Herndon, the "speech as published" in books by Francis Bicknell Carpenter and Osborn H. Oldroyd "makes Lincoln say things which he never uttered nor any sane man would utter." It "makes Lincoln a fool or a hypocrite or an ass or a combination of the three."1

To Herndon, "the speech is false and I want to nail it so." To prove this, Herndon asks Graff as well as another "liberal," William Henry Burr of Washington, D.C., to look into the circumstances of the speech, who heard it, who wrote it out, "&c &c &c."

Unknown to Herndon, Carpenter and Oldroyd probably used contemporary newspaper reports of Lincoln's remarks. On Sept. 8, 1864, the Washington Daily Morning Chronicle quoted Lincoln: "In regard to this Great Book, I have but to say, it is the best gift God has given to man. All the good the Saviour gave to the world was communicated through this book. But for it we would not know right from wrong. All things most desirable for man's welfare, here and hereafter, are to be found portrayed in it."2
The University of Illinois acquired Herndon's letter from the Abraham Lincoln Book Shop of Chicago before 2000.

1. Carpenter, Six Months in the White House with Abraham Lincoln: The Story of a Picture (New York: Hurd and Houghton, 1866), 199; Oldroyd, The Lincoln Memorial: Album-Immortelles... (New York: G. W. Carlton & Co., 1882), 340.
2. The Collected Works of Abraham Lincoln, ed. Roy P. Basler et al. (New Brunswick, N.J.: Rutgers University Press, 1953-55), 7:542.
